Award.AwardTitle: Representation Theory, Integrable Systems and Quantum Fields: Emphasis Year at Northwestern University, May 19-23, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main purpose of this grant is to fund the workshop and conference, "Representation Theory, Integrable Systems, and Quantum Fields: Emphasis Year at Northwestern University," running May 12-16 (workshop) and May 19-23 (conference) in 2014. Northwestern has a long history of successful 'emphasis years' following the broad pattern of the proposed activities. This year's emphasis will be placed on connecting new physics to mathematics. Recent advanced in physics pioneered by Nekrasov-Shatashvili, Alday-Gaiotto-Tachikawa, and Kapustin-Witten have spawned hundreds of papers and interest around the globe. A mathematical perspective has been offered by Maulik-Okounkov and there is related work of Goncharov-Kenyon. These results should be understood not only on their own merit, but also as a part of a broader emerging relationship between integrable systems, representation theory and quantum fields. The workshop and conference will do just that. The bulk of the proposed funding will support graduate students and postdocs either directly, by funding their participation, or indirectly by funding speakers at the graduate workshop. These students will largely be US nationals from US institutions, thus furthering the goal of the solicitation to support the development of professional mathematicians in the United States.

The general theme of the program is to explore the interplay between symmetry groups and the physical systems in which they arise. Physical phenomena have analogous mathematical descriptions, and vice versa: the geometric Langlands program has an analogue in a dimensional reduction of a topologically twisted supersymmetric gauge theory, through the work of Kapustin and Witten. The Alday-Gaiotto-Tachikawa conjecture relates two-dimensional conformal field theory to four-dimensional supersymmetric theories. A mathematical manifestation of this conjecture is the action of Virasoro and W-algebras on the cohomology of moduli spaces of bundles on a complex surface constructed by Maulik and Okounkov. Integrable systems relating to string compactification on singular Calabi-Yau threefolds have descriptions as dimer problems in statistical physics, which in turn relate to cluster integrable systems (Nekrasov-Shatashvili, Kenyon-Goncharov). All of these phenomena will be explored in the workshop and conference. The conference webpage is located at the following address: http://www.math.northwestern.edu/emphasisyear/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In May, 2014, we held a conference on Representation Theory, Integrable Systems and Quantum Fields (as reported previously). In April, 2016, we held a follow-up mini-conference on "Representation Theory, Integrable Systems and Quantum Fields" at Northwestern University. The website is at 

http://sites.math.northwestern.edu/RTISQF/
The mini-conference was a continuation of the conference at Northwestern, focusing on the major topics in representation theory and mathematical physics.  Eight speakers gave one-hour talks. The topics included 
1) geometric representation theory and its interplay with symplectic geometry, and integrable systems;
2) Mirror symmetry and related topics in symplectic geometry, stable homotopy theory and number theory;
3) Cluster algebras and combinatoric representation theory.
We had a total of 31 participants, including13 graduate students, 9 postdocs and 10 professors from different universities in the US and Canada. The conference was a great opportunity for mathematicians working in representation theory and mathematical physics to communicate on the central topics in these fields and interchange their different points of view.

 

There were 8 speakers. The talks covered several topics including Hitchin fibrations, cluster algebras, Springer’s theory, symplectic resolutions, mapping class groups, and mirror symmetry.

In more detail, Schaposnik discussed about Higgs bundles, branes and their applications in Langlands duality and integrable systems. Li compared several combinatorial models in the study of cluster algebras, and explained their relations to mirror symmetry. Losev focused on the classifications of deformations of symplectic singularities and then applied them to establish a version of Kirillov’s orbit method for semisimple Lie algebras. Nevins explained a few fascinating aspects of Springer’s theory and symplectic resolutions. Treumann looked for symplectic constructions that are mirror to nontrivial algebraic geometry in positive characteristic. Keating presented parallels between properties of Dehn twists in dimension 2 and in higher dimensions, with an emphasis on relations in the mapping class group. Tanaka introduced an infinity category constructed out of Lagrangian cobordisms, which conjecturally is equivalent to a version of Fukaya category.

There were 31 total attendees. A list of participants has been included below:

Rustam Antia-Riedel, Tsao-Hsien Chen, Kevin Costello, Chris Elliott, Honghao Gao, Sam Gunningham, Aron Heleodoro, Xin Jin, Theo Johnson-Freyd, Ailsa Keating, Clemens Koppensteiner, Li Li, Ivan Losev, Matthew Mahowald, David Nadler, Thomas Nevins, Itziar Ochoa de Alaiza, Laura Schaposnik, Linhui Shen, Shiyu Shen, Nan Shi, Pyongwon Suh, Hiro Lee Tanaka, Sean Taylor, David Treumann, Josh Wen, Daping Weng, Jesse Wolfson, Eric Zaslow, Peng Zhou, Alex Zorn.
